arm_group.description: This group will receive their insulin via vial/syringe
Patients receiving insulin via insulin pen

brief_summary.textblock:
This research is to determine the use of insulin pens compared to syringe and vial therapy
      in adults newly begun on insulin therapy during their hospital stay.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Improved Efficacy, Safety and Compliance to Administer Insulin in Pen vs. Vial and Syringe

detailed_description.textblock:
This research is to determine the use of insulin pens compared to syringe and vial therapy
      in adults newly begun on insulin therapy during their hospital stay.  Patients will have no
      prior experience using insulin or other self-administered injectable medicine.  The study
      will examine which method of administering insulin reduces dosing errors, causes a lower
      incidence of low blood sugars, increases adherence to therapy and with which method patients
      are more satisfied.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Adult in hospital and diagnosed with diabetes; must have no prior experience using
             insulin or other self-administered injectable medicine.  they must be able to prepare
             an injection and to self administer the insulin using either a pen device or syringe
             and vial.  They must be willing to monitor their blood sugar three times per day and
             keep a diary of their sugar measurements and insulin doses.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Previously treated with injectable medicine

study_pop.textblock: Adults newly begun on insulin therapy during their hospital stay.

intervention.description: Insulin pen was compared to administration of insulin using standard syringes.

clinical_study.official_title: A Study of Improved Efficacy, Safety and Compliance to Administer Insulin in Pen vs. Vial and Syringe

primary_outcome.description: Whether the method of administering insulin would: 1) reduce dosing errors as measured by direct observation of patient performance, 2) reduce the risk of hypoglycemia, 3) increase adherence to insulin, 4) improve patient satisfaction.Dosing accuracy was measured by direct observation of subject's performance at follow-up visits.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System

secondary_outcome.measure: Reduce the Risk of hypoglycemia (assessed by patient diary)
Adherence to prescribed dose of insulin (assess patient diaries and observation of used pens/vials)
Patient satisfaction with method of insulin administration measured by questionnaire.

clinical_study.source: North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System

lead_sponsor.agency: North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System
